item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“Siggi, post:18, topic:449658”][quote author=s1gma link=topic=552548.msg4048763#msg4048763 date=1342300278]
or, use an ide that autotabs when you’re writing code and can autoformat doing much more than just tab insertion

Download eclipse

CTRL+I

problem solved.

The thing is I hate IDEs, and I’m used to plain text editing, and IDEs do everything automatically, and I usually type a closing bracket in before I even realize that the IDE did it for me.

lolwat do you actually understand what locking and synchronised blocks are for? i don’t see the point in firing off a new thread purely to run the source transformer anyway, unless you intend to parse multiple files with multiple threads in the future (advised). oh and please implement Runnable. also in the case of

I know what the locking is for, but for some reason I just automatically assume another developer is an idiot, and tries to use this program in his own program as a library, and lock it in case he calls start() twice by accident in two threads at the same time.
For example:

final JavaTab jt = new JavaTab(myFile); new Thread(new Runnable() { public void run() { jt.start(); } }).start(); jt.start();

please don’t use characters equivalent number as although the comment says what it is, it shouldn’t have to have a comment when you use the literal character instead (x == ‘{’)

I never thought of that, but then again, I sometimes like to confuse people.

on the note of naming, you may want to refer to an apostrophe-enveloped value as a literal character rather than a stringTypeB

There, you can see my laziness, this shows I’m way too lazy to change the names of variables, so I just copy/paste the variable and just add A and B to the end. I wouldn’t do it if the name of the variable would be far from correct. (If an car is stepping on the brakes, I wouldn’t make the brake variable turningLeftB) However when I’m finished with the code I usually use the text editor’s find/replace feature to change it all, if I could remember which ones were A/B, but as you can see, I didn’t do it for JavaTab.[/quote]the assumption isn’t needed, and if the developer knows what he’s doing (concurrently executing JavaTab on multiple files) the reason for multiple runs would be valid. ps confusion isn’t good

finally, don’t be lazy. try and stick to good names.

item.title: JavaTab - clean your code!
item.dc:creator: @Siggi Siggi
item.description:
@Siggi wrote:

Good day all!

I’ve written a program that automatically tabs your Java code to make it easier to read and understand. The reason I did this is because when I look at java code written by lazy people, such as most RSPS server and client bases, they never add tabs, which makes it really hard to read and understand the process that the code takes.

It works with all java code, and doesn’t cause compiler errors, I’ve tested this on a 508 server source and compiled it no problem.

The program is attached, I’ve only made compiler and runner for Mac OS X and Linux, if you have Windows shouldn’t be that hard for you to fix it up.

DOWNLOAD!

HOW TO USE:

For entire directory

For a single java file

You can also specify the tab type using “-t” parameter before the list of files/folders you want to auto tab.
Valid options:
-t tab - Each tab will be one tab character “\t”
-t space - Each tab will be 4 spaces
-t spaceX - X is the number of spaces you want to put, instead of 4
Examples:

Please give comments on what you think, how it could be improved, do you think its useful/useless? etc.

There’s no virus in the program, but if you’re paranoid, here’s the source code, so you can copy/paste and compile it yourself.

[code]import java.io.*;

public class JavaTab {
public static void main(String args[]) {
String tab = “\t”;
for (int i = 0; i < args.length; i++) {
if (args[i].equals("-t")) {
i++;
if (args[i].equals(“tab”)) {
tab = “\t”;
} else if (args[i].equals(“space”)) {
tab = " “;
} else if (args[i].startsWith(“space”)) {
int spaceCount = Integer.parseInt(args[i].substring(5));
tab = “”;
for (int j = 0; j < spaceCount; j++) {
tab += " “;
}
}
}
File file = new File(args[i]);
if (file.isFile()) {
new JavaTab(file, tab).start();
} else if (file.isDirectory()) {
scanPath(file, tab);
}
}
}
private static void scanPath(File folder, String tab) {
File files[] = folder.listFiles();
for (int i = 0; i < files.length; i++) {
if (files[i].isDirectory()) {
scanPath(files[i], tab);
} else if (files[i].getName().toLowerCase().endsWith(”.java”)) {
new JavaTab(files[i], tab).start();
}
}
}
private final File file;
private final String tab;
public JavaTab(File file, String tab) {
this.file = file;
this.tab = tab;
}
private boolean started = false;
private final Object lockObject = new Object();
public void start() {
final JavaTab jt = this;
synchronized (lockObject) {
if (!started) {
started = true;
new Thread(new Runnable() {
public void run() {
jt.run();
}
}).start();
}
}
}
private void run() {
try {
BufferedReader reader = null;
{
CharArrayWriter caw = new CharArrayWriter();
FileReader fr = new FileReader(file);
char[] buffer = new char[4096];
int c = 0;
while ((c = fr.read(buffer, 0, buffer.length)) != -1) {
caw.write(buffer, 0, c);
}
reader = new BufferedReader(new CharArrayReader(caw.toCharArray()));
}
FileWriter fw = new FileWriter(file);
int tabCount = 0;
String line = null;
while ((line = reader.readLine()) != null) {
boolean inStringTypeA = false;
boolean inStringTypeB = false;
int tabsToPut = tabCount;
line = line.trim();
CharArrayReader car = new CharArrayReader(line.toCharArray());
int x = 0;
int lastChar = 0;
while ((x = car.read()) != -1) {
if (!inStringTypeA && !inStringTypeB) {
if (x == 123) tabCount += 1; // Open Bracket {
if (x == 125) tabCount -= 1; // Close Bracket }
}
if (lastChar != 92) { // If last character is not
if (x == 34 && !inStringTypeB) inStringTypeA = !inStringTypeA; // Open/Close Speech Quote Str
if (x == 39 && !inStringTypeA) inStringTypeB = !inStringTypeB; // Open/Close Apostrophe Str
}
if (tabCount < tabsToPut) tabsToPut = tabCount;
if (lastChar == 92)
lastChar = 0;
else
lastChar = x;
}
for (int i = 0; i < tabsToPut; i++) {
fw.write(tab);
}
fw.write(line);
fw.write("\n");
}
fw.close();
} catch (Exception e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}
}
}[/code]
